Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Networking Infrastructure: Configurable, High-Speed, Extensible Research Bandwidth (CHERuB)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Configurable, High-speed, Extensible Research Bandwidth (CHERuB) project connects the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) and the San Diego Supercomputer Center (SDSC) to national research networks at 100Gbps for collaborative research in data-driven science and engineering. CHERuB supports multi-institutional data transit over research networks such as Internet2 and ESnet for analysis and distributed computing, such as that provided by SDSC's Gordon project, and collaboration, such as that facilitated by UCSD's LHC Tier-2 site. It includes an upgrade of the campus gateway to support CENIC's newly-installed 100G pipe between San Diego and Pacific Wave's 100G regional research network collective, and intra-campus infrastructure to facilitate high-speed access by targeted research activities.

CHERuB enables advancement of knowledge in large cosmology, atmospheric science, high-energy physics and other fields by providing high-bandwidth connectivity between the researcher and national networks. The project allows scientific instruments to efficiently transport big data, removing the network as bottleneck in the course of scientific discovery. Simulation, visualization, measurement, and interactive experimentation is streamlined. Exploration of OpenFlow/OSCARS coordination with real-world data flows will help other research users understand how best to set up projects for large pipes/big data.

Beyond the initial science drivers, CHERuB establishes infrastructure to serve additional research projects on campus and across the country. UCSD shares what we learn via CHERuB about transmission and processing of big data across the national network infrastructure with other campuses. High bandwidth makes possible new instructional activities that cross institutions and locations, such as telemedicine and distributed distance learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CHERuB project successfully created a 100G research networking connection from the UC San Diego campus border connecting research facilities and resources at UCSD to collaborators and facility users on Internet2 and ESnet. 

This connection has enabled high-speed transmission of big data from the Large Hadron Collider CMS experiment to the Tier-2 site at UC San Diego and to partner sites around the U.S., allowing more researchers to download more data and contributing to ongoing discoveries related to the CMS experiment. It also facilitated users of the data-intensive Gordon HPC system at SDSC to efficiently move big data to and from Gordon to other NSF resources such as TACC Stampede, TACC Wrangler, and NCSA Blue Waters. The PI of this project effortlessly moved 70 TB of cosmological simulation data between these sites for the purposes of scientific analysis.

CHERuB has enabled the Prism@UCSD Science DMZ to provide multiple 40G connections to on-campus high-speed users, extending the reach of their big data-dependent research beyond the campus edge. It has also inspired and enabled the development of the Pacific Research Platform, which originated at UC San Diego and has led to high-speed big data connections between research institutions worldwide, enabling innovative research through sharing of big data that could not formerly have occurred.

In addition to these infrastructure connections, CHERuB is enabling access to very large databases -- both from campus (by external researchers) and from the outside world (by internal researchers). In the past, extracts would have to be formed prior to data transmission; it is sometimes hard to make decisions about what subsets of data to select without conducting computational analysis on the dataset. The ability to download an entire large dataset, conduct needed preliminary analysis, and extract the critical data needed for longer term analysis is enabling new approaches to research.

The CHERuB 100G connection will continue to serve research at UC San Diego into the forseeable future, making big data research possible that would not otherwise have been feasible at this instution and enabling collaborations across institutions that would not have previously been contemplated. This service is available to all campus researchers who may have need of high-speed networked connections.
